ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



The Rio Bravo - Rocklin facility uses anhydrous ammonia to help maintain air quality compliance of the emission stack, specifically, reducing NOx (NO and NO2) emissions.  Ammonia is a hazardous substance that must be handled properly in order to prevent accidental releases and injuries.  It is the policy of Rio Bravo - Rocklin to conduct all operations (including the ammonia thermal DeNOx system) in a safe manner.  This policy extends to all employees and contractors at the facility.  Rio Bravo - Rocklin implements this policy towards chemical and general safety through on-going employee participation, training, written operating procedures, maintenance, inspections, safety committee meetings, and safety reviews/evaluations.  These programs are in effect at the facility to prevent the accidental release of ammonia.  In the event of an ammonia accident, the facility has an Emergency Action Plan to notify the appropriate authorities and safely evacuate the facility.



STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE



General Overview



The Rio Bravo Rocklin facility utilizes ammonia in the Thermal DeNOx system installed on the Combustion Engineering circulating fluidized bed combustor which processes biomass for generating steam.  Biomass fuel is charged to the boiler and is combusted in the fluidized bed. Particulate laden flue gases travel upward through the combustion chamber.  At the top, the flue gases flow into a cyclone and the cleaner flue gases exit overhead.  Ammonia is injected into the outlet flue gas piping downstream of the cyclone.



The DeNOX process occurs in a specific temperature range with the ammonia mixing with the flue gas and reacting with the NOx. Anhydrous ammonia is used as the reducing agent.  



Facility Details



The ammonia injection system uses approximately 200 tons of ammonia annually for the thermal DeNOx system at Rio Bravo Rocklin. 



The system involves the storage

and vaporization of liquid ammonia, and injection of the vaporized ammonia into the boiler through injection points (nozzles) to facilitate mixing with the flue gas. 



Liquid ammonia is brought onsite by trucks complete with an on board ammonia vapor compressor that transfers the ammonia to the ammonia storage tank.  The liquid ammonia is stored in a horizontal ammonia storage tank with a 12,000 gallon capacity.  The facility keeps the vessel filled to approximately 85% capacity.  

 

To ensure that an adequate supply of ammonia vapor is available for the process, a vaporizer may be utilized.  The vaporizer is located at an elevation lower than the bottom of the ammonia storage tank so it can be gravity filled with liquid ammonia.  The purpose of the vaporizer is to maintain the vapor pressure in the storage tank above 45 psig, which is the vapor pressure of liquid ammonia at 30?F.  Due to the large surface area of the storage tank, heat input to the system from the vaporizer is normally unnecessary except during times of low ambient temperature.



Ammonia vapor from the head space of the tank is directly injected into the boiler for the thermal DeNOx process. 



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



In order to operate the Thermal DeNOx system, the facility complies with the following risk management regulations:



-OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM);

-EPA's Risk Management Program (RMP); and

-California Accidental Release Prevention Program (CalARP). 



In addition, common industry standards, policies, and procedures are utilized to ensure safe practices are being performed.  The ammonia system employed by the Rio Bravo - Rocklin facility is equipped with various system controls and status indicators intended to minimize potential ammonia related accidents and to allow operators to monitor system operations.  This monitoring system is comprised of pressure indicators, as well as other system safeguards and met

hods for allowing facility operators to effectively monitor and control operations.  There is an ambient ammonia detector at the facility. The detector is located above the Storage Tank.  The detector has a high level alarm set at 15 ppm and a high high level alarm set at 25 ppm. The detector alarms in the Control Room. At high high level, the control valves on the Storage Tank are automatically closed. 



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



EPA's RMP Program defines "accident" as the following:



"The release must be from a covered process and involve a regulated substance held above its threshold quantity in the process.



The release must have caused at least one of the following:



?    On-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage (?68.42(a)); or

?    Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place (?68.42(a))."



Rio Bravo's Five Year Accident History was reviewed during the PHA Revalidation on June 29, 2012. There have been no significant releases of ammonia at the facility in the last five years (June 2007 - June 2012) that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity of 100 pounds or the state requirement mandating immediate reporting of any release or threatened release of a hazardous material.  There have been two "near misses" at the facility in the last five years (June 2007 - June 2012). 



The first "near miss" occurred when a forklift operator struck a section of ammonia piping with a forklift. The piping was bent, but no ammonia was released. The forklift operator was in a location where he should not have been. The operator was released as a result of this incident.



The second "near miss" occurred while a technician was manually checking the ammonia level in the Storage Tank. When checking the level, a small droplet of ammonia was released. A full incident investigation was conducted, and as a result, all technicians now wear a face shield and protective gloves when manually checking t

he ammonia level in the Storage Tank. The facility is also considering installing a liquid level column with sight glasses on the Storage Tank.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



The facility has an Emergency Action Plan (EAP) in effect at the facility.  This EAP was designed to meet the following objectives:  



-save lives;

-minimize and avoid injuries;

-protect the environment; and

-minimize property damage.



The EAP provides the notification procedures and evacuation routes for emergencies that may arise at the facility.  The EAP is reviewed and updated at least once per year to ensure compliance with the PSM, RMP, and CalARP regulations.  Facility personnel receive annual training regarding the emergency procedures.



Rio Bravo - Rocklin personnel circulate throughout the facility, taking note of unusual conditions in any portion of the system.  In the event that an ammonia leak is discovered, the person nearest to the leak will alert any personnel in the immediate area who are unaware of the danger, and the Control Room Operator.  The Control Room Operator will contact the Plant Manager to evaluate and ascertain the significance of the leak.  If the ammonia leak is considered minor and/or minimal, the repair will be conducted by the Rio Bravo - Rocklin maintenance staff.  An outside contractor may be contacted to further assist in the potential repairs to the equipment pertaining to the ammonia system.  For major ammonia leaks, emergency agencies will also be notified as necessary as outlined in the Emergency Action Plan.  Action is promptly taken to mitigate the leak so normal operations can resume.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



The Process Hazard Analysis study, performed on August 8, 2007, and revalidated on June 29, 2012, generated mitigation measures (recommendations) to improve safety at the Rio Bravo - Rocklin facility located in Lincoln, California.  The mitigation measures include additional training, key maintenance-related tests/inspe

ction, and enhanced emergency response policies and procedures.  The Rio Bravo - Rocklin safety committee is planning to complete several items, including the recommendations, over the next year, as a continual effort to provide a safe work environment for their employees.  These changes include the following items:



1. Continue to train all employees in the facility Safety Plan/Programs.



2. Continue to have employee involvement in Safety Plan Development.



3. Continue employee involvement through safety team participation.



4. Continue internal and external safety audits/inspections and implement changes as needed.



 

DATA ELEMENT NOTES



The Emergency Action Plan outlines evacuation routes, notification procedures, and reporting procedures in the event of an emergency, which could include fire, ammonia release, blackout, and earthquake.
